questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a long history of heavy smoking presents with complaints of shortness of breath and chronic coughing. He is diagnosed with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and started on regular use of ipratropium bromide. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Ipratropium bromide acts as a muscarinic receptor antagonist.

It is a semisynthetic derivative of atropine and acts selectively on bronchial muscles to produce bronchodilation. It is used extensively for acute exacerbations of COPD and rhinorrhea.

Ipratropium blocks all subtypes of muscarinic receptors thereby antagonizing the inhibition of ACh release. It is a short-acting muscarinic antagonist that is administered in a powdered or nebulized form via metered dose inhaler around 3-4 times a day.

Nebulized ipratropium bromide may increase the risk of glaucoma in elderly patients and thus cautiously used to avoid exposure of the drug to the eye. Paradoxical bronchoconstriction may occur with ipratropium bromide when given along with hypotonic nebulizer solution and antibacterial additives, such as benzalkonium chloride and EDTA.

Other options:

Option A: Muscarinic receptor agonists such as pilocarpine directly act on the muscarinic receptor to produce actions similar to acetylcholine. 

Muscarinic receptors are those that are selectively stimulated by muscarine and blocked by atropine. They are mainly of three subtypes: M1 (increasing intestinal secretions), M2 (mediates vagal bradycardia), and M3 (constriction of visceral and bronchial smooth muscles, vasodilatation in vascular endothelium causing penile erection).

Option B: Ganglionic stimulants can be divided into selective nicotinic agonists (nicotine and varenicline) and nonselective/ muscarinic agonists (acetylcholine and pilocarpine).

Option C: Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors such as physostigmine, neostigmine, and galantamine inhibit cholinesterase enzyme (protects acetylcholine) and produce cholinergic symptoms.

Related Pearl: Ipratropium vs Tiotropium

 

Ipratropium

Tiotropium

Duration of action

Short

Long

Frequency of administration

3-4 times/day

Once daily

Antimuscarinic action

Non-selective

Relatively selective for M1 and M3 receptors

Paradoxical broncho

constriction

Present *

Absent

*Attributed to the nebulizer solution and other additives added. Blockade of prejunctional M2 receptors that normally inhibit acetylcholine release also can contribute.

Related Pearl: Acetyl Choline Receptors

Type

Location

Nicotinic (ionotropic) receptors

NM

Neuromuscular junction

NN

Autonomic ganglia

Muscarinic (metabotropic) receptors

M1, M4, M5

CNS

M2

Heart

M3

Glands and smooth muscle

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy presents with shortness of breath and bluish discoloration of lips. Chest X-ray shows a boot-shaped heart due to an upturned cardiac apex. The finding seen on the chest X-ray is due to:
questions.solution:
The clinical description of shortness of breath and bluish discoloration of lips, along with boot-shaped heart on chest X-ray, suggests tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). The findings of a boot-shaped heart due to the upturned cardiac apex is due to right ventricular hypertrophy.

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is a cyanotic congenital heart condition. The four cardinal features of the tetralogy of Fallot are as follows:

  • Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Obstruction of the right ventricular outflow tract (subpulmonary stenosis)
  • An aorta that overrides the ventricular septum
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy

The image given below shows cardinal features seen in TOF:

 

Children with TOF usually present with dyspnea on exertion, they characteristically assume a squatting position for relief of dyspnea. During anoxic spells, children start crying, become dyspneic and cyanotic, and may eventually lose consciousness. 

A chest x-ray of a child with TOF typically shows a boot-shaped heart due to the upturned cardiac apex. This is mainly because of right ventricular hypertrophy. Other chest x-ray features in tetralogy of Fallot are:

  • Pulmonary oligaemia (due to pulmonary stenosis)
  • Normal size heart (heart failure is not a feature in TOF)
  • Right-sided aortic arch (25%)

Medical management with oral propranolol prevents cyanotic spells, surgical correction is the definitive treatment of choice. The intravenous administration of prostaglandin E1 can be tried to keep ductus arteriosus open while awaiting surgery.

Given below is a chest x-ray showing a boot-shaped heart (cœur en sabot in French).

Related Pearl: Important radiological signs in cardiology

Sign

Pericardial effusion
Boot shaped heart/ Coeur-en-sabot
Fallot’s tetralogy
Gooseneck sign
Endocardial cushion defects
Box-shaped heart
Ebstein's anomaly
Jug handle appearance
Primary pulmonary artery hypertension
“3” like appearance of the aorta
Coarctation of aorta
Egg-on-string appearance
Transposition of great vessels
Egg in cup appearance, Pericardial calcification
Constrictive pericarditis
Snowman’s heart, Cottage loaf appearance, Figure of Eight appearance
Total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation
Scimitar sign
Partial anomalous pulmonary venous return
Calcification in the heart wall
Carcinoid syndrome
Calcification of ascending aorta
Atherosclerosis, Syphilis
Hilar dance on fluoroscopy
Atrial septal defect
Batwing appearance
Pulmonary edema
Pruned tree appearance of the pulmonary vasculature
Pulmonary artery hypertension

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in some congenital heart defects

Boot shaped heart - Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Egg on string appearance - Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA)

 

Snowman's heart appearance or figure of 8 appearance - Supracardiac TAPVC

 

Box Shaped Heart - Ebstein's Anomaly

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with chronic kidney disease presents to the OPD  with exercise intolerance, fatigue, and shortness of breath.  On examination, she is found to have severe pallor.  Which of the following is least likely to be a cause for these findings?
questions.solution:
Sickle cell anemia is not a feature of chronic kidney disease (CKD).

Common causes of anemia in CKD include:

  • Erythropoietin deficiency
  • Diminished red blood cell survival
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Iron deficiency
  • Vitamin B12 and folate deficiency
  • Hyperparathyroidism (due to bone marrow fibrosis)
  • Hemoglobinopathy

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain, shortness of breath, and vomiting for a few hours. She is on ovulation induction therapy for infertility. The sonogram of both her ovaries is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the sonogram showing enlarged ovaries meeting in the midline having large cysts are suggestive of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome. 

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is characterized by mul­tiple ovarian follicular cysts accompanied by increased capillary permeability. It happens most often as a complication of ovulation­ induction therapy for infertility. It occurs due to the stimulation of vascular endo­thelial growth factor (VEGF) expression in granulosa-lutein cells by hCG.

They often present with shortness of breath, abdominal pain, and gastrointestinal disturbances like nausea, vomiting, and oliguria.

Abdominal pain occurs due to ovarian enlargement and accumulation of peritoneal fluid. Increased vascular permeability and loss of fluid, protein, and electrolytes into the peritoneal cavity cause ascites and result in hemoconcentration. Hemoconcentartion causes hyperviscosity and leads to hypercoagulability.  

Hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, leukocytosis, pleural effusion, and pericardial effusion can be associated with OHSS. 

Some of the risk factors for OHSS:

  • Polycystic ovarian syndrome
  • Young age
  • High estradiol during ovulation induction
  • Pregnancy

Classification of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome

Grade I Abdominal discomfort or distension
Grade II

Abdominal discomfort or distension + nausea and vomiting or diarrhea+ Enlarged ovaries (5-12 cm)
Grade III Ultrasonographic evidence of ascites
Grade IV Clinical evidence of ascites/hydrothorax/breathing difficulty
Grade V All of the above with decreased blood volume, hemoconcentration, diminished renal perfusion and function, and coagulation abnormalities. 

This condition can be prevented by

  • Withholding hCG in a cycle if there are more than 20 follicles on ultrasound and E2 level rises to 3000 pg/ mL.
  • Albumin 5% infusion in 500 mL lactated Ringer’s solution during and after oocyte retrieval
  • Dopamine agonist cabergoline 0.5 mg daily for 8 days starting on day 1 of hCG.

OHSS is primarily managed with general supportive care. Paracentesis is performed to ameliorate abdominal discomfort and relieve respiratory discomfort.

Other options:

Option B- Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) is the most common endocrine disorder of the reproductive age group. Patients with PCOS present with menstrual irregularities, hirsutism, acne, infertility, etc.

Sonographic criteria for PCOS include:

  • >/= 20 small cysts ( 2 to 9 mm diameter) or,
  • Increased ovarian volume (>10 mL), or both

The ultrasound examination image shown below is of PCOS showing enlarged ovaries with multiple cysts. 


Option C- Hyperreactio luteinalis is a condition in which one or both ovaries develop multiple large theca lutein cysts. They typically occur after the first trimester due to luteinization of the follicular theca luteal layer in response to exceptionally high HCG. They are commonly seen in:

  • Gestational trophoblastic disease
  • Multiple gestational preganancy
  • Fetal hydrops
  • Placentaomegaly

Ultrasonography shows a "spoke wheel pattern". Most of them resolve spontaneously after delivery. Surgical management is only required if it is complicated by torsion or hemorrhage. 

The below image shows bilaterally enlarged ovaries with multiple theca luteal cysts as in hyperreactio luteinalis.

 


Option D- Hematometra is a condition in which menstrual outflow obstruction traps the blood and distends the uterus. Depending on the level of genital blockage, blood can distend:

  • Vagina called hematocolpos
  • Uterus called hematometra
  • Fallopian tubes called hematosalpinx

Patients usually present with cyclic midline pain, low backache, amenorrhea, and pelvic fullness. A large uterus can compress the urinary bladder, and rectum causing urinary retention and constipation. blood may get infected and lead to pyometra causing fever and leukocytosis.

Ultrasonography is the diagnostic tool that shows a smooth, symmetric hypoechoic enlargement of the uterine cavity. Relieving the obstruction and evacuation of blood is the primary management.

The below ultrasonographic image shows a smooth, symmetric hypoechoic enlargement of the uterine cavity suggestive of hematometra.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with shortness of breath and fatigue. She has a medical history of limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis. Her pulmonary function test results are given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above PFT pattern shows near-normal FVC, increased FEV1%, and markedly decreased DLCO. This along with the given history is suggestive of pulmonary artery hypertension(PAH). It is more commonly associated with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis.

Option B: Interstitial lung disease is a restrictive lung disease. In ILD, the FVC is usually,<80% of the predicted value. It is more commonly associated with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis.

Options C and D: Congestive heart failure and bronchiectasis have obstructive pathology. They would have decreased FEV1% and normal DLCO.

Related Pearl: PFT for obstructive vs restrictive diseases

PFT

Obstructive disease

Restrictive disease

FVC

Decreased

Decreased (<80% predicted)

FEV1

Decreased (<80% predicted)

 Decreased

FEV1% (FEV1/FVC)

Decreased (<0.7)

Normal/ increased (>0.7)

FEF 25-75

<50% predicted

Normal/ decreased

TLC

Normal/ increased

Decreased

RV

Increased

Decreased

DLCO
  • Normal or increased in asthma
  • Decreased in emphysema
  • Decreased in intrinsic restrictive disease
  • Normal in neuromuscular or musculoskeletal restrictive disease

FVC: Forced Vital Capacity

FEV1: Forced expiratory volume in 1 second

FEF 25-75: Forced expiratory flow at 25-75% vital capacity

TLC: Total lung capacity

RV: Residual volume

DLCO: Diffusion capacity of lung for Carbon monoxide.

Related Pearl: Diffuse Cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis Versus Limited Cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis

Characteristic feature Diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis
Skin involvement

Rapid progression

Involvement of the skin areas proximal to the knees or elbows or over the anterior chest, trunk, or abdomen

Slow progression

Limited to face and skin distal to the elbows and knees

 

 
Raynaud’s phenomenon

Less severe

 

Short history 

More severe; commonly associated with critical limb ischemia.

Long history 
Musculoskeletal Severe arthralgia, carpal tunnel syndrome, and tendon friction rubs Mild arthralgia
Pulmonary manifestation Interstitial lung disease more common Pulmonary artery hypertension (PAH) is equal in both
Scleroderma renal crisis Occurs usually <4 years of disease onset Very rare
Calcinosis cutis Less common More common & prominent
Auto-antibodies

Anti-topoisomerase I (Scl-70)

anti-RNA polymerase III

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with history of squamous cell carcinoma lung presents with shortness of breath. Her chest X-ray is shown below. Which among the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows the golden S sign which is seen in the right upper lobe collapse.

Golden S-sign is seen on both PA chest radiographs and on CT scans in the right upper lobe collapse. It is named because this sign resembles a reverse S shape, and is therefore sometimes referred to as the reverse S-sign of Golden. 

Although typically seen with the right upper lobe collapse, the S-sign can also be seen with the collapse of other lobes. It is created by a central mass obstructing the upper lobe bronchus. It should raise suspicion of a primary bronchogenic carcinoma. It can also be caused by other central masses, such as metastasis, primary mediastinal tumor, or enlarged lymph nodes.

The additional finding in this X-ray is the presence of calcified breast implants.

questions.text: Helen is a 78-year-old woman who is a smoker for the past 30 years and has a history of angina. She presents to your accident and emergency (A&E) department with chest pain worse on inspiration and shortness of breath. Her ECG shows signs of:
questions.solution:
• The ECG changes are classic of pulmonary embolism showing S1Q3T3.

ECG findings in pulmonary embolism

  • Sinus tachycardia
  • Complete or incomplete RBBB (seen in the given ECG also)
  • S1Q3T3: deep S wave in lead I, Q wave in III, inverted T wave in III

questions.text: An elderly man is diagnosed with ischemic heart disease and is started on propranolol. After some days, he is brought to the emergency department with a history of difficulty in breathing. He says that he is a smoker and has had difficulty breathing for the past several years. However, it has worsened after taking propranolol. The mechanism that is mainly responsible for worsening his breathing difficulty is
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the symptoms of respiratory difficulty in the patient have worsened after the intake of propranolol. The mechanism that is mainly responsible for worsening his breathing is β2 blockade. Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker. It blocks the β2 receptors in bronchial smooth muscle and prevents bronchodilation. Therefore, it should not be given to patients who have asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

Other important side effects of beta-blockers are:

  • Cardiovascular system- 
    • Beta blockade decreases myocardial contractility. Therefore, it can exacerbate decompensated heart failure.
    • Decreased heart rate- Bradycardia, In patients with heart block it can cause fatal bradyarrhythmias
    • Abrupt discontinuation of β receptor antagonists after long-term treatment can exacerbate angina
  • Respiratory system- bronchospasm due to blockade of β2 receptors in the bronchial smooth muscles.
  • Central nervous system- fatigue, sleep disturbances, and depression.
  • Exacerbation of peripheral artery disease occurs due to the blockade of β2 receptors in the vascular smooth muscles.
  • It can slow the recovery from insulin-induced hypoglycemia as they inhibit catecholamine-mediated glycogenolysis.
  • This class of drugs is also known to mask the hypoglycemia symptoms in diabetic patients. The symptoms of hypoglycemia which are mediated by the adrenaline release will be masked as beta-blockers will not allow adrenaline to react and interact with its beta 1 receptor.  
  • Hyperkalemia- blockade of β2 receptors prevents the entry of extracellular potassium into the cells.
  • Sexual dysfunction in males
  • They can also alter the serum triglyceride and HDL-cholesterol concentrations. Beta-blockers such as atenolol, metoprolol, and propranolol increase the levels of triglycerides and decrease the levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol. Other beta-blockers like labetalol, pindolol, and acebutolol do not have any effect on lipid levels.

Autonomic innervation of the lung.

Relaxation of the tracheal and bronchial smooth muscles is brought by β2 receptors. Contraction is by the M2 and M3 cholinergic receptors. Therefore, important drugs that used for bronchodilation are 

  • β2 selective agonists like salbutamol, terbutaline, salmeterol, formoterol, etc,
  • Antimuscarinic agents like ipratropium bromide, tiotropium, aclidinium, and umeclidinium.

Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker. It acts equal affinity to both β1 and β2 receptors. It does not have intrinsic sympathomimetic activity and does not block α receptors.

Important adverse effects of propranolol are:

Cardiovascular system- It can cause or exacerbate heart failure in patients with compensated heart failure, acute myocardial infarction, or cardiomegaly. In patients with partial or complete AV conduction defects, β antagonists may cause life-threatening bradyarrhythmias. Sudden discontinuation of beta-blockers after prolonged use can exacerbate angina and may increase the risk of sudden death.

Respiratory system- It blocks the β2 receptors in bronchial smooth muscle and can cause bronchospasm.

Nervous system- It causes fatigue, sleep disturbances (including insomnia and nightmares), and depression.

Metabolism- It delays the recovery from insulin-induced hypoglycemia.

Overdosage may lead to hypotension, bradycardia, prolonged AV conduction, and widened QRS complexes, seizures, depression, hypoglycemia, and bronchospasm.

Related Pearl: Cardioselective beta blockers: Mnemonic

Cardioselective Beta blockers Act At Nothing But Myocardium Exclusively.

  • C: Celiprolol ( III )
  • B: Bisoprolol
  • A: Acebutolol
  • A: Atenolol
  • N: Nebivolol ( III )
  • B: Betaxolol ( III )
  • M: Metoprolol
  • E: Esmolol

( III ) - Third generation beta blockers. All the others are second generation beta blockers

questions.text: A young farmer on a hike developed sudden shortness of breath, chest pain, and cough with salty phlegm. He was rushed to the emergency and stabilized. A CT scan showed the following. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the CT image showing the 'water lily sign' is suggestive of a ruptured pulmonary hydatid cyst.

Hydatid disease or echinococcosis is a zoonotic infection caused by the Echinococcus species of flatworms. Its life cycle consists of dogs as definitive hosts and humans as intermediate hosts.

Primary hydatid cysts most commonly occur in the liver. Most patients are asymptomatic but when symptomatic, the patient presents with hepatomegaly, pain, and obstructive jaundice.

The 2nd most common site is the lung, specifically the lower lobe of the right lung. Symptomatic patients present with cough with salty phlegm, fever, chest pain, and, hemoptysis. Silent cysts may present as an emergency due to rupture.

Computed tomography (CT) scan is accurate for detecting hydatid cysts. If there is disruption of the inner layers of the cyst, the following signs may be noted:

  • Water lily sign/ camalote sign - air-fluid level with a floating membrane (as shown below)
  • Rising sun sign/ serpent sign - a double-wall, dry cyst with crumpled membranes lying at its bottom 
  • Empty cyst sign - when all the contents are removed 

Ultrasound is the most commonly used modality to diagnose echinococcus. The ultrasound of an active hydatid cyst shows multiple septations and a rosette or honeycomb appearance (as shown below)

Serology: Detection of serum anti-echinococcal antibodies using indirect hemagglutination (IHA), indirect immunofluorescence, ELISA, and slide latex agglutination test can be used to support the clinical diagnosis.

Treatment :

Pulmonary hydatid disease the mainstay of treatment is surgery. Various surgeries that may be performed are cystotomy, segmentectomy, pneumonectomy, etc. 

Hepatic hydatid disease in the early stages can be treated with puncture, aspiration, injection, and re-aspiration (PAIR). Albendazole 4 days before the procedure, continued till 4 weeks afterward. Surgery is the treatment of choice when PAIR is not possible. The preferred surgical approach is pericystectomy. Since recurrence is common, pre and postoperative albendazole for 2 years is recommended.

Other options: 

Option B: A CT scan in acute pulmonary edema would show peribronchial opacities (batwing distribution) and thickening of interlobular septae in the lung base and apex (corresponds to Kerley lines on X-ray).

Option C: A CT scan in acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is likely to show bilateral pulmonary infiltrates. 

Option D: A CT scan in acute mountain sickness (AMS) is likely to reveal patchy opacities, most often in the right middle lobe. The common presenting features are cyanosis, tachypnoea, tachycardia, and elevated body temperature. AMS may also lead to the development of non-cardiogenic high-altitude pulmonary edema.

Related Pearl: Indications and contraindications of puncture, aspiration, injection, and re-aspiration (PAIR) in hydatid cyst

Indications:

  • Relapse cyst, infected cyst, cyst >5 cm in different liver segments
  • Patients who refuse surgery or where surgery is contraindicated
  • Pregnant women, children < 3 years of age
  • WHO - type CE1 and type CE3a (transitional cyst)

Contraindications:

  • Cysts in lung
  • Cysts communicating with bile duct
  • Cysts with multiple septae—honeycomb cysts
  • Inaccessible cysts
  • Hyperechogenic cysts
  • Calcified cysts

questions.text: A woman from rural South America presents with fever, shortness of breath, and swelling of the eyelids. Echocardiography reveals biventricular dilatation, with massive cardiac enlargement. The image of the vector responsible for transmitting the disease is given below. Name the vector.
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with echocardiography findings of dilated cardiomyopathy, are suggestive of Chagas disease. It is caused by Trypanosoma cruzi. The vector responsible for the transmission is the reduviid bug. 

Transmission occurs by the rubbing of the feces of the reduviid bug into bite wounds or eye, blood transfusion, and transplacental spread.

Chagas disease is endemic to North, Central, and South America. Trypanosoma cruzi exists in three forms:

  • Epimastigotes- in the reduviid bug
  • Trypomastigotes- in the bloodstream
  • Amastigotes- intracellular replicating form

Clinically, the infection course of Chagas disease is divided into acute and chronic phases.

In the acute phase, the majority of the patients will be asymptomatic. Fever, regional lymphadenitis, chagoma (localized subcutaneous nodule at the bite site), and the Romana's sign (unilateral swelling of the eyelids) may be seen.

The chronic phase is characterized by the following findings:

  • Chagasic dilated cardiomyopathy with marked bilateral ventricular enlargement. This may lead to congestive heart failure presenting as shortness of breath. Endomyocardial biopsy shows fibrosis and the presence of intracellular parasites.
  • Megaesophagus and megacolon. 

Diagnosis is confirmed by demonstrating trypomastigotes on microscopy of blood smears or polymerase chain reactions during the acute phase. In the chronic phase, detection of anti-T. cruzi IgG or endomyocardial biopsy is helpful.

Treatment of Chagas disease is most effective when administered early in the course of infection and has a lesser efficacy in chronic Chagas. Benznidazole and nifurtimox can be used for the treatment.

The image below shows Romana's sign.

Other options:

Option A: Dermacentor tick is a type of hard tick responsible for transmitting rocky mountain spotted fever.

Option B: Soft ticks are known to transmit relapsing fever.

Option D: Tsetse fly is responsible for transmitting Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense and Trypanosoma brucei gambiense, which cause African sleeping sickness.

questions.text:
A patient with shortness of breath is diagnosed to have acute pulmonary edema. His chest X-ray, on PA view, revealed lines in the periphery of the lungs that are perpendicular to the pleural surface. What are these lines?

PA view- Postero-anterior view
questions.solution:
Lines in the periphery of the lungs that are perpendicular to the pleural surface in a patient with pulmonary edema are suggestive of Kerley B lines.

Kerley lines are septal lines that are seen when the interlobular septa in the pulmonary interstitium become prominent. It can be due to lymphatic engorgement or edema of the connective tissues of the interlobular septa. These are usually seen when the pulmonary capillary wedge pressure reaches 20-25 mmHg.

Types of Kerley lines: 

Kerley A lines- They extend radially from the hilum to the upper lobes and cross the normal vascular markings. These are oblique lines that are <1 mm thick, 2-6cm long, and course towards the hila. They represent thickened interlobular septa that contain lymphatic connections between the perivenous and bronchoarterial lymphatics in the lung parenchyma. The best modality for the demonstration of Kerley A-lines is HRCT.

Kerley B-lines - These are seen in the periphery of the lungs and are seen perpendicular to the pleural surface. These are thin 1-2 cm long lines. These are usually seen at the lung bases and represent thickened subpleural interlobular septa.

Kerley C-lines - These are short lines that do not reach the pleura (i.e. not B or D lines) and do not course radially away from the hila (i.e. not A-lines).

Kerley D-lines - These are the same as Kerley B lines, except that they are seen on lateral chest radiographs in the retrosternal air gap (the lucent area behind the sternum).

questions.text: A 17-year-old Chinese boy presented with prolonged fatigue, shortness of breath, and swelling in the legs. His echocardiography was suggestive of dilated cardiomyopathy. Which of the following nutritional deficiencies can explain his condition?
questions.solution:
The patient is probably suffering from Keshan's disease, which is due to selenium deficiency. It is endemic dilated cardiomyopathy that affects children and women of childbearing age in some areas in China.

The nutritional deficiencies that can lead to cardiomyopathy are:

  • Thiamine
  • Selenium
  • Carnitine
  • Calcium
  • Phosphate
  • Magnesium

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented to you with shortness of breath and dry cough for the past 3 months. On examination, the following skin lesions were seen. You will order all of the following investigations except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and examination findings of erythema nodosum are suggestive of sarcoidosis. CD4/CD8 ratio in bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) fluid, not blood, is used for diagnosis of sarcoidosis.

Erythema nodosum is inflammation of the subcutaneous fat (panniculitis) seen in sarcoidosis.

The investigations used in the diagnosis of sarcoidosis include:

  • Serum ACE (angiotensin-converting enzyme) levels - elevated
  • BAL- lymphocytosis and increased CD4/CD8 ratio. A ratio of >3.5 in BAL is strongly supportive of sarcoidosis.
  • PET-CT scan - to identify areas of granulomatous disease
  • Gallium scan shows the following signs:
    • Panda sign- due to bilateral involvement of parotid and lacrimal glands in sarcoidosis
    • Lambda sign- due to bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymph nodes which resembles lambda (λ)
  • Biopsy showing non-caseating granulomas in a patient with features of sarcoidosis confirms the diagnosis.

The image given below shows the Panda sign:

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of smoking for the past 30 years is admitted to the ward with cough and shortness of breath. The spirometry result is given below. Which of the following physical finding is unlikely to be associated with his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with a history of smoking for the past 30 years now presenting with cough and shortness of breath, with the spirometry showing an obstructive pattern (coved in appearance of the expiratory limb) suggests chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Clubbing is not a physical finding seen in COPD.

Patients with COPD present with cough, sputum production, and dyspnea on exertion. General physical examination may show cyanosis (option A) in the lips and the nail beds. COPD is also accompanied by severe weight loss due to the loss of subcutaneous adipose tissue (option C). This occurs due to inadequate food intake and high inflammatory cytokines such as TNF-α.

On respiratory examination, a prolonged expiratory phase and an expiratory wheeze may be noted. Hyperinflation of the lungs gives rise to the characteristic barrel-shaped chest (option B) seen in these patients. Severe airflow limitation causes the patients to sit in a tripod position to and use the accessory muscles of respiration. 

Clubbing of the digits is not a sign of COPD. Its presence in a chronic smoker with COPD most commonly indicates the development of lung cancer in such a patient.

Related Pearl: PFT for obstructive vs restrictive diseases

PFT

Obstructive disease

Restrictive disease

FVC

Decreased

Decreased (<80% predicted)

FEV1

Decreased (<80% predicted)

 Decreased

FEV1% (FEV1/FVC)

Decreased (<0.7)

Normal/ increased (>0.7)

FEF 25-75

<50% predicted

Normal/ decreased

TLC

Normal/ increased

Decreased

RV

Increased

Decreased

DLCO
  • Normal or increased in asthma
  • Decreased in emphysema
  • Decreased in intrinsic restrictive disease
  • Normal in neuromuscular or musculoskeletal restrictive disease

FVC: Forced Vital Capacity

FEV1: Forced expiratory volume in 1 second

FEF 25-75: Forced expiratory flow at 25-75% vital capacity

TLC: Total lung capacity

RV: Residual volume

DLCO: Diffusion capacity of lung for Carbon monoxide.

questions.text: An infant presents to the emergency department due to difficulty breathing, constipation, and anorexia. Upon examination, the physician notes flaccid paralysis. A toxin screen of the stool identified the agent. What is the mechanism of action of the toxin?

choices.text: ADP ribosylation of eukaryotic elongation factor 2 (eEF-2)

questions.solution:
The characteristic clinical history of flaccid paralysis, constipation, difficulty breathing, tox screen of stool, and age are suggestive of infant botulism (also called floppy baby syndrome) caused by Clostridium botulinum.

The flaccid paralysis is due to the toxin that blocks the release of acetylcholine.

Clostridium botulinum in adults causes food poisoning.

Other options:

Option a: ADP ribosylation of eukaryotic elongation factor 2 (eEF-2) describes toxins found in Corynebacterium diphtheriae and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

Option b: ADP ribosylation of Gi, an inhibitory subunit of the G protein describes Bordetella pertussis.

Option c: ADP ribosylation of GTP-binding protein describes the toxins found in ETEC and Vibrio cholerae.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the hospital with complaints of difficulty breathing. Chest X-Ray shows "eggshell" calcification. Histopathology of the lung shows the following. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's radiological and histopathological features are seen in silicosis.

Eggshell calcification refers to the fine rim of calcification seen at the periphery of a mass (usually a lymph node)

Silicotic nodules are characterized by concentrically arranged hyalinized collagen fibers surrounding an amorphous center in the hilar lymph nodes and the upper zones of the lungs.

When it is rimmed by thin sheets of calcification in the lymph nodes, they are appreciated radiographically as “eggshell” calcification.

Image: Histology of silicotic nodule showing a central area of whorled collagen fibers, with a more peripheral zone of dust-laden macrophages and rim of lymphocytes

Other options:

Option B- Asbestosis shows ferruginous bodies on histopathology
Option C-Lung hamartomas appear as well circumcised nodules/masses. They do not show silicotic nodules in histopathology.
Option D-Tuberculosis present with cavitary lesions in the upper lobes of the lungs. Histopathology reveals caseous necrosis with multinucleated giant cells.

Related Pearl: Eggshell calcification of lymph node on chest X-ray

Eggshell calcification refers to fine calcification seen at the periphery of a lymph node. Causes are -

  • Silicosis (most common)
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Post radiotherapy
  • Post-irradiation lymphoma
  • Histoplasmosis
  • Blastomycosis
  • Amyloidosis
  • Tuberculosis

questions.text: The parents notice that their child is tired and that he has shortness of breath on climbing stairs and while lying down. What is the first investigation that you would do?

choices.text: MRI to rule out enlarged heart

questions.solution:
The first investigation to be done for a child who feels shortness of breath on climbing stairs and in the supine position is a chest x-ray.

The child having shortness of breath on climbing stairs is known as dyspnea on exertion. The most common cause is congestive heart failure. The child feeling shortness of breath in the supine position is orthopnea. It is relieved on sitting or standing.

Respiratory causes include asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder (COPD), pneumonia, and pulmonary embolism. Cardiovascular causes include congestive heart failure(CHF), pulmonary edema, valvular heart defect, and pulmonary hypertension. 

Evaluation begins with assessing the airway, breathing, and circulation of the patient. Oxygen saturation can appear normal at rest, and hence oxygen saturation during physical activity should be obtained. A chest x-ray is the first diagnostic test which can show pulmonary pathology or pumonary edema and other signs of CHF that could help in identifying the cause and further evaluation.

Other options:

Option A: An echocardiogram can be done if the chest X-ray is abnormal. It is done to evaluate cardiac function, valvular function, and pericardial space.

Option C: Spirometry is done when the chest x-ray is normal. It is done to determine lung function. Abnormal spirometry can indicate either an obstructive pathology such as asthma, or COPD or a restrictive disease such as interstitial fibrosis. 

Option D: Cardiac MRI (Magnetic resonance imaging) is an emerging modality done to look for cardiomegaly. It is for the accurate evaluation of left and right ventricular mass, size, and function. It is also used for localizing ischemic and non-ischemic causes such as myocarditis.

questions.text: A man presented with salt and pepper skin changes on his chest and back and with shortness of breath. A CT revealed fibrotic changes in the lower lobe of both the lungs. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Salt-and-pepper appearance is characterized by the presence of patchy hypopigmentation and hyperpigmentation of the skin manifesting as depigmentation with perifollicular pigmentary retention. This along with lung fibrosis is seen in systemic sclerosis.

This appearance may also be seen in areas of repigmentation in lesions of vitiligo.

The image below shows salt and pepper appearance of skin over the abdomen seen in systemic sclerosis.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female presented with shortness of breath and pleuritic chest pain. Chest X-ray revealed pulmonary metastases as shown in the image below. Which of the following primary tumours is most likely possible?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows numerous calcified pulmonary metastases, which is commonly seen usually due to osteosarcoma.

Pulmonary metastases usually occur from thee primary tumours involving the breast, GI tract, kidney, testes; head and neck tumours or bone and soft tissue sarcomas. The metastases may spread either through a haematogenous route (common) or a lymphatic and endobronchial route (rare).

Radiological features of pulmonary metastases:

 

A. Haematogenous metastases: They usually appear as multiple discrete pulmonary nodules measure up to a few cms in size.

Appearance:

  • The nodules are usually spherical, with a well-defined margin. However, an irregular edge may be seen with metastatic adenocarcinoma, and an ill-defined margin is suggestive of haemorrhage, classically choriocarcinoma (option a).
  • Cavitation of the pulmonary nodules may be seen with metastatic squamous carcinoma, such as carcinoma of the cervix (option c).
  • Calcification is rarely seen. If present, it is commonly due to osteosarcoma. Rarely, calcified deposits may be seen due to chondrosarcoma or mucinous adenocarcinoma.

Location:

  • Metastases are usually bilateral, and within the sub-pleural region, where the tumour cells are trapped in the smallest vessels.
  • The pulmonary nodules may be seen predominantly in the bases due to greater gravitational perfusion.
  • Presence of pneumothorax together with cavitation of subpleural metastases may occur due to a soft-tissue sarcoma (option d).

 

B. Endobronchial metastases:

  • They are rare and may occur due to primaries such as melanoma, renal, colorectal and breast carcinomas.
  • The metastases may appear as a hilar mass, with or without airway obstruction.

 

C. Miliary metastases:

  • They appear as multiple, small parenchymal nodules measuring approximately 2 mm in size, resembling 'millet seeds'.
  • They are rare and may be seen with thyroid and renal carcinomas.

 

D. Tumor emboli:

  • In rare cases, the tumour emboli may block pulmonary arteries leading to pulmonary arterial hypertension.
  • It may occur in primaries such as hepatocellular carcinoma, or tumours involving breast, renal, stomach, prostate, or choriocarcinoma.

questions.text: A  58-year-old man presented to the casualty with complaints of increasing shortness of breath, lightheadedness, and palpitations. He had an irregularly irregular pulse and blood pressure was 120/70mm Hg. His ECG is given below. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The patient is in atrial fibrillation but his hemodynamic status is normal. So the treatment of choice is IV Ibutilide.

Ibutilide is a class III antiarrhythmic drug that has a rapid onset of action. It restores sinus rhythm by prolonging the action potential duration and effective refractory period.

It is administered at a dose of 1 mg over 10 minutes. If necessary, a second dose can be administered 10 minutes after the first.

If there is evidence of hemodynamic deterioration, immediate cardioversion is the treatment of choice.

Cardioversion is a synchronized administration of shock as the timing is typically synchronized with the R waves or QRS complex of a cardiac cycle. On the other hand, random administration of shock anywhere in between a cardiac cycle is termed as Defibrillation which is non-synchronized.

However, the mechanism for both processes is quite similar. The electric current is made to travel from the negative to the positive electrode in such a way that it traverses the entire myocardium at once to conduct a simultaneous contraction of each cell of the heart muscle. It is made to interrupt any ongoing abnormal electrical activity by terminating it so that the sinus node can take back the charge and resume its normal pacemaker activity.

Indications for electrical cardioversion Indications for defibrillation

Supraventricular tachycardia

(atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia [AVNRT] and atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia [AVRT])

Atrial fibrillation

Atrial flutter (types I and II)

Ventricular tachycardia (with a pulse)

Any patient with re-entrant tachycardia with narrow or wide QRS complex (ventricular rate >150 bpm) who is unstable (eg, ischemic chest pain, acute pulmonary edema, hypotension, acute altered mental status, signs of shock)

Pulseless ventricular tachycardia (VT)

Ventricular fibrillation (VF)

Cardiac arrest due to or resulting in VF

 

Cardioversion is typically performed under induction or sedation using a short-acting agent such as midazolam, unless the patient is hemodynamically unstable or if cardiovascular collapse is imminent. Defibrillation is more of an emergent maneuver and, when necessary, should be preferably performed in conjunction with or prior to the administration of induction or sedative agents.

Energy may be delivered through mainly two waveforms in defibrillators that are monophasic or biphasic.

Monophasic defibrillation delivers a charge in only one direction as opposed to biphasic defibrillation delivering a charge in one direction for half of the shock and in the electrically opposite direction for the second half.

Biphasic waveforms are adopted in newer defibrillators as they deliver a more consistent magnitude of the current which successfully terminates arrhythmias at lower energies than monophasic waveform defibrillators.
 
Energy selection for defibrillation or cardioversion. Following are the guidelines for initial energy requirements issued by the American Heart Association in 2010.

Atrial fibrillation energy requirements are as follows:

  • 200 Joules for monophasic devices
  • 120-200 Joules for biphasic devices

Atrial flutter energy requirements are as follows:

  • 100 Joules for monophasic devices
  • 50-100 Joules for biphasic devices
Ventricular tachycardia with pulse energy requirements are as follows:
  • 200 Joules for monophasic devices
  • 100 Joules for biphasic devices
Ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia energy requirements are as follows:
  • 360 Joules for monomorphic devices
  • 120-200 Joules for biphasic devices
